item.title: How I Made This Blog - Part 3
item.description: I last left off describing how I built this website and pushed it to GitHub for the first time. Once you’ve pushed a Hugo site to a GitHub repo, you can turn on GitHub pages and host your site live at username.github.io. I went with this option initially, but as I went through the process of customizing my site, a lot of sensitive information began to pile up in my config.

item.title: How I Made This Blog - Part 2
item.description: Intro Want to make a website with Hugo, just like this one? In this post, I’ll outline how I did it, step by step. Step 0: Conquer your procrastination This step took me a while. Try not to get distracted, and remember that if you don’t have time for something, you make time for it. Stop right there!! Step 1: Choose a static site generator and a theme As mentioned in the previous post, I wanted a static site generator that could create blazingly fast websites.

item.title: How I Made This Blog - Part 1
item.description: Intro When it comes to personal projects, I can be a terrible procrastinator. There’s just too many things to do and too many ways to do them - especially for creating a personal blog. I’ve made false starts using all of the following and more: Blogger Wordpress Squarespace Jekyll Gatsby Pelican A tumblr page A twitter feed From-scratch static HTML hosted on AWS Enigmatic pictures on Instagram Since you’re reading this now, you might have inferred that I eventually settled on something - that something is Hugo on Github Pages.
